reviewText: The game itself is amazing, providing a very addictive environment that also will force the player to use the restroom one too many times. There are a few Easter Eggs, most funny, and one lethal. The objective of the game is to hold off for 5 mandatory nights, as well as two that are optional following the completion of the fifth night. This game was based off of a Maryland pizza parlor, called Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, carrying the motto, Where food and entertainment come to life
date: straight from the restaurant itself. The restaurant was closed down in 1987 and is still being investigated because of an animatronic coming to life and biting into the frontal lobe of what used to be (but she is still alive) a very happy customer. For those that love a good scare but hate spending money on the movies, here is a very great alternative!

reviewText: Viral hype aside, this game does a better job of fostering paronoia and an unsettling atmosphere than most games of it's type, Indy or otherwise. The ebbs and flow of the game work in direct synergy with the gameplay, which while it is limited in scope, the extra resource management coupled with it's frantic pacing ensure you won't have much time to think about it. The surreal scenario only enhances the game further, as the unfamiliarity and constant looming uncertainty drive home the point that YOU do not belong here, YOU are the trespasser in this territory.\n\nSomewhere down the line we'll all look back at this and laugh about the whole thing, but for now it is the high-water mark for the BOO! Haunted House" Genre. Very sensibly priced."

reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's is a cute and very original resource management and strategy game. In the game you take on the role of a security guard who has to keep track of four animatronic robots without using too much power. The game is surprisingly fun and gets challenging at later levels. The part where the animals catch you can be somewhat startling, although that just adds to the fun.

reviewText: There are a lot of people who say that this game isn't scary, or at least isn't as scary as it's hyped up to be. That's fine. What makes something scary" is subjective
date: after all. Even if you don't have a fear of animatronics or don't react much to jumpscares
recommended: the one thing that I think we can agree on is this: The tension in this game is very high.\n\nManaging only one resource--power--seems simple enough but the room for error dwindles as the difficulty increases each night. Even if you know each character's behavior and how to monitor them

reviewText:
Realistically speaking? For how it's made, it's not a bad game. It's not scary, truthfully, but the suspense keeps you on edge. You expect it yet you don't expect it. It's not a bad game at all.

-Would I recommend this game? Naturally, given the jumpscares, no. But with how the game is designed, both in mechanics and visuals, I'd say yes. The game is comprised of a series of GIFS, not animated models like what we're used to today, this is more akin to older games. Very well done for that fact alone.
-I sound like a broken record, but it does a good job of keeping you on edge, trying to determine which of the animatronics will pop up and from where. Bonnie and Chica, of course are fixed on sides, Foxy can come from either side and Freddy pops up when least expected under some occasions.
-Even for each night lasting nine minutes, the suspense makes it feel so much longer.
And the atmosphere adds to this. Eery.

My recommendation for the game, personally, is to add more background compared to the skimpy details observed on the walls. Storyline based details. News stories clipped to a bulletin board only take us so far.

Hopefully there will be an expanded sequel.

reviewText:
This game is not like any I've played before, It has it's own atmosphere of paranoia. The gameplay, albeit a little clunky, is very good; the graphics are amazing and pretty managable, and the storyline of the game just leaves you wondering. I nearly had a panic attack playing this fantastic indie game on stream!

My only problem with the game is that there is no options menu to manage the game window, sound, video quality, and mouse sensitivity. However, it did not take away from my enjoyment of this game!

10/10, I would reccommend this to everyone I know!

reviewText: FNAF is a good horror game that can mess with your nightmares you had as a kid about animatronics, and it gives that feeling of paranoia because this game has things you don't usually expect. For all the negative reviews, I say you don't really have anything that says the game is bad, most of the time I see negative reviews that really say the game is frustrating and was not scary, now I don't really see a problem in that, but uh I really find it hard to believe you weren't scared. I see other things negative reviews say,  like it wasn't worth $5, some terrible immature joke bad interviews and like the such, and I hate how people say this game is a youtuber streamer trap, really? Why...ok, first of all, I have a youtube channel yet I uploaded FNAF but did I get popular? No! All I got were like 12 views. But uh, going back to the other things like this game isn't worth $5...dude...that's like...pocket change in the world right now and yet you're complaining this game is too expensive? HA what a joke. But going back to this game, I can say it truly made me scared and paranoid at the same time. This game is definitely worth your time and worth your money, the sequel deserves even better praise. Oh, and might I say this game was when Scott Cawthon (the creator) was very close on giving up onon the entire video game industry because the fact that critics for his other games said that his characters looked like scary animatronics.

reviewText:
Invite the Demons into your Computer with Five Night's At Freddy's, a unique, one-of-a-kind Horror Experience brought forth from the crazy/genius mind of developer Scott Cawthon. No movement, no fancy mechanics. Simple point-and-click horror at its best. These monsters take the form of your inner childhood fears and stalk the corridors of a derelict pizzeria, eager to, without heistation, force your weak human form into a walking Iron Maiden and kill you in the most horrific way imaginable. One second they're there, the next, gone. But, always watching you.

Simple mechanics. Open a door, close a door. Turn on a light, turn it off again. Open camera view, close camera view. Five Nights (give or take a few, if you play long enough) alone with 4 (5 *wink*) murderous animatronics. The question falls to you.

Are you ready, for when Freddy comes for you?

reviewText:
This game has a more intense atmosphere than Amnesia, and it's scarier than Slender and SCP Containment Breech combined.

10/10

-Great game!

reviewText:
When I first played this, it scared the crap outta me. I don't play any horror games that much, but this game is one of the most scariest and terrifing game ever. So many jumpscares though. I think I like this game a lot.

This game is about the animatronics named Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy attempting to kill you and stuffing you in a suit. So you play as the security guard named Mike Schmidt and your objective is to survive Night 1-5, 6, and 7 from 12 A.M. through 6 A. M.  without wasting powers. Like I said, the game is really scary so you might wanna try it out.

Now the question is this: Are you ready for Freddy? Because I'm ready for Freddy.

reviewText:
Five Nights is the epitome of horror games. It is fear in gaming distilled to its purest form; an experience that forces you to give it your full attention and focus while it strips you of any sense of balance or safety. It is unnerving and upsetting to its core.

What truly makes this remarkable is how simple the game is. There is really only one action: Close the Door button only and always when you think you're about to be attacked. Close too early, and you waste power. Close too late, and you are doomed.

All the rest is window dressing to this, but what is there is so perfectly executed. I must emphasize that what I say is praise. The simplicity is to its benefit, providing you with absolutely nothing to distract you from your feelings of foreboding, dread, and terror.

This is, in many ways, the perfect horror game.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's is an indie horror game made by Scott Cawthon. You have to survive 5 nights at a Chuck E. Cheese-esque place called 'Freddy Fazbear's Pizza'. What do you have to survive? Animatronics, yes, animatronics. The four main animatronics are Freddy, Bonnie, Chica and Foxy who all have different attack patterns; different ways to get to YOU. Here are some things that Five Nights at Freddy's does well: Making the player feel challenged: Five Nights at Freddy's starts out very easy but then ramps up the difficulty, especially in the later nights. Making the player feel helpless: Now, it goes without saying that if you were stuck in a place with 4 killer robot furries, you'd feel pretty helpless. And sense you're in a tiny office just waiting for you to get stuffed into a suit, it amplifies it. Fear: Five Nights at Freddy's will obviously be scary, right? Yes, it is scary. If you fail to stay alive through a night, you will be killed by one of the robots in a... jumpscare... A cheap jumpscare? Really?" you might ask. Yeah
recommended: but it isn't the jumpscare that scares you
hoursPlayed: it's not knowing when it will happen. If the death is predictable
voteText: then it isn't as scary.\nAs a final review for Five Nights at Freddy's
helpfulPercent: I give it a 9.9/10."

reviewText:
Take 1: Just shut both the doors and wait out the night.
What do you mean the power ran out? It's only 3 am!"

Take 2: Only shut the blast doors when something is right outside my room.
Survived Day 1 and all the little children yelled "Yay!" I find it demeaning.

Take 2
date:
Day 2:
"WHAT DO YOU MEAN THEY MOVE MORE IF I'M NOT WATCHING THEM?!?!?"

The game would be less frightening if I could just lock myself in and only die of Oxygen loss. Instead I worry about should I check the cameras (my job) or wait till something's in the hall near me and slam the door shut.

I only recommend if you're in need of a heart attack.

11/10"

reviewText:
So dis game

I played a demo of it off the indiedb, and I gotta say, y u so scared?

All it is is a robot furry Swiggity Swooty Comin' For the Booty simulation game in which you defend your homestead (A dank and terrible office with an iPad, monitors from the 70's, silly posters, mil-spec blast doors, and a battery that couldn't power my refrigerator) from yiff happy robotic furries that want to break down your homestead and convince you to perform special favors in the early morning hours before standard operation begins, a standard night at the office in my opinion. You can tell it is a robot furry yiff defense simulator because the fox is always the most hype to come for the booty.

Time to rant, why could the company not afford a mechanic, if they were able to afford electro lock high tension spring actuated blast doors? I'm pretty sure I could hire a team of professional mechanics for the price of just one of those doors.
Just sayin'

People complain about the lack of settings, but if your computer is anything higher up than a blender hotwired to an alarm clock with the toaster expansion module then you should be able to play it just fine you whiners. (Hell, even I can run it.)

Buy it now, cus it's better than RE6, it actually rustled up my jimmies, It's better than the DayZ, because this game actually has mechanics that work and an engine that isn't made out of a waffle iron.

So order now, and we wont send our animatronic butt pirate fox after you for further convincing!

reviewText: This game only seems scary when you play it. You can watch Youtubers play it or your friends and it just won't give you the same feeling as when you play. What's that feeling? A quickly escalating scense that somethings about to happen to you. And when it doens't happen right away then the pressure just builds. The pressure is probably what makes this game the best. It adds to the already scary atmosphere, and makes you beg for Freddy to let you live until 6 A.M. This is defininately one of the best horror games I've ever played. This game is truely a masterpiece. If you like horror games or haven't played any and want to try them out, this is a great game for you! To top it all off, it's only 5 dollars! It's worth so much more!

reviewText: I recommend this game as Five Nights At Freddy's is a huge twist to all horror games. The hugest problem is though that once you know how each animatronic move pattern the game can become a cake walk, however they change their patterns up each night. This ment I could pass Night 2-7 (4/20 mode) on my first try aslong as you follow a routine each night. A good thing to know before you play is that F2 resets the game but ESC quits the game.\n\nOn the overhand I don't recommend this game to anyone with a faint heart or is elderly as you will expect lots of jumpscares. (Which only so far I've had 1 and that was only on my first night.) If however you like some horror and jumpscares this is the game for you.

reviewText: Well you all knew this was coming so here it is, Five Night's at Freddy's, a point and click horror game made by Scott Cawthon has his final attempts to make a video game, but of course now it's Final Fantasy all over again. You play as the night guard at a family pizzarea called Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. Sounds simple enough... if it wasn't for the animatronics out to kill you. Your only advantages of defending yourself is using the sercurity camera to check on where the animatronics are, a light switch to see if anyone is coming to get you, and a door switch to close the doors, while dealing with a limited amount of power. It's a good game with a decent amount of challenge.

reviewText: I just don't know what went wrong. After trying so hard to appreciate and even like this game, I found myself having the opposite of fun and wanting some sort of hourly wage just for playing this. People finally managed to talk me into playing this game
date: and FNAF not only doesn't compare well to other titles I've been pressured into buying but just doesn't seem to be a game at all. The player has very little actual control and a lot is left up to random chance. Just about the only feedback the game provides the player with is jumpscares. Winning a level doesn't feel rewarding at all.\n\nThe best way to win this game is by refusing to play. You can then construct the lore of an employee of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza suing the owner for wreckless endangerment after Night One, making millions of dollars in the resulting media fallout and cheesy horror movie series deal. The CIA then swoops in and has the infernal machines cold-rolled and then melted down into a solid cube to be launched into the sun by NASA. The creator of the animitronics is placed on a watch list and told to never create another machine again under threat of assassination. THE END.

reviewText:
I'm actually very disappointed in this game. It really isn't anything more than a click game. You click to check cameras and you click to close doors. Keep doing that until it's 6am in-game and you're done for the night. Repeat again the next night. Congratulations on completing the game in under an hour.

Honestly, I had hoped for way more than it delivered. I was expecting a horror game for PC. What I got was something that wouldn't look out of place on some casual browser-game site. The 'scares' are just jump-scares. There's no tension because there's no need to worry. It's just a question of click until they get too close and then shut the doors till they leave again.

It just doesn't live up to the hype.

reviewText:
A spectacularly-frightening game that is honestly worth every penny. What you need to do in this game is to survive 5 nights as a security guard in Freddy Fazzbear's Pizzariea. This requires that you utelize cameras, lights, and the two doors that lead into your room, to monitor and protect yourself from the deadly animatronic mascots that wander around at night.
But why is this scary? Here is why:

-You can't move from your security room. All you can do is wait for them to come to you!
- Everything you can do drains power. So you have to balance security vs. sustianing the power.
- The monsters will look at you and watch your every move throughout the camera waching, and when they show up at your freakin doorstep.

And much, much more. I don't really want to give too much away about this game because of how terrifying it is when you know less about it.

Simply put; BUY THIS GAME! Is your body ready for Freddy?

reviewText:
The question is should you buy Five Nights at Freddy’s?
Yes

Five Nights at Freddy’s is a first-person horror game developed by Scott Cawthon.  The game revolves around you as a security guard and five animatronics who will attempt to get into your office.  The object of the game is, of course, to keep them from getting in using your video cameras and the doors.  There is a setback, you only have a limited amount of power and failure to limit your power usage wisely results in a jump scare.

The gameplay is fairly simple and quickly gets repetitive.  You slide your mouse to the bottom of the screen to pull up your cameras.  From there you can select different rooms to view excluding the kitchen, whose camera is disabled for some reason.  Sliding the mouse down will exit out of the camera view and put you back into the office where you can open/close the doors and flicker the lights on either side of you.  While simple and repetitive, this gameplay choice surprisingly enhances the game as it gives the player a sense of hopelessness at they can’t move or try and hide from the animatronics.  The animatronics themselves are reminiscent of the Chuck E Cheese animatronics and have different attack patterns.  For example, Foxy requires you to view the camera in ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ constantly or he will rush to your door resulting in a jump scare and a game over.

The jump scares are affective in scaring the player, but the game as a whole is enough to fill anyone with dread.  Once the infamous phone guy hangs up you’re left in a startlingly silent environment for a few seconds before you begin to hear strange sounds.  Random laughs, pots and pans clattering, and strange whistling sounds can be heard and are enough to put anyone on the edge of their seats.  The atmosphere is brilliantly crafted, creating a desolate environment that fits the story it tells.

The greatest thing about FNAF is its story.  While most horror games have no story or shove its story in your face, FNAF forces you to root around if you want to learn more.  At the beginning of the first four nights a man, lovingly referred to as Phone Guy, will leave you a voice message that both instructs you on how to play, and tells small tidbits of the restaurant itself.  After that, however, you are on your own for the rest.  Posters of news clippings will change telling you more about the lore of the place, but most else is left to the imagination.

In the end, this game is worth the five bucks you shell out to buy it.  Not content to just be youtube bait, this game goes above and beyond what is considered to be a good horror game.  Simple gameplay, actually scary antagonists and environments, and a story that gets more interesting the more you dig into it.  The game is not perfect, the gameplay does get repetitive and the animatronics do loose some fear points as you get used to them.  However with the games that have been released to us as of late, it is refreshing to see a unique and enjoyable experience from a game that should not have delivered so much with so little.

I also made a video review on Fnaf.  I say the same thing, but if you perfer a visual review then you can view it here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cYxPSPJV3Ns&feature=youtu.be

reviewText: It's hard to find something to say about Five Nights at Freddy's that hasn't already been said. I'm a huge fan of horror and have played just about every horror game, watched every horror movie (even the cheesy ones) and read every online ghost story and creepypasta there is so obviously, I'm a bit more harsh when judging a piece of horror. I can't necessarily say Five Nights at Freddy's is scary" as much as it is tense. VERY similar to Slender in that the game relies on the tension caused by the feeling of paranoia and the feeling of being hunted to get into the player's mind. The problem though is that this game's tension is built more so out of the fact that you don't want one of the animals jumping up and screaming at you loudly
date: not so much that you actually feel in danger like you would in Slender or games similar. Because of that and the fact that while you don't know EXACTLY when the jump scare will occur but get a good idea of when it's coming (animal is close to your room in the camera feed
recommended: clicking sound when trying to turn on light
hoursPlayed: etc.) leaves this game feeling more like a digital version of a jack in the box rather than a real
voteText: horror experience. All that being said
helpfulPercent: I still very much enjoy this game and (especially considering the price) would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in it. A good piece of horror? No. A good experience? Yes."

reviewText:
Night Trap with furries. While the concept might sound kind of lame and hokey, in execution it's a damned fine minimalist horror game.

You're an underpaid security guard for a kid's entertainment center, and during the night shift, the animatronic animals come to life and wander the halls. You must check your camera feed constantly to see where they're ambling about, power the lights outside your office to see if any of them are at the door, and slam the doors in their face before they horrifically mutilate you by stuffing you into a spare suit. You have a limited amount of dwindling power to see you through the night, and checking the video feed, powering the door lights, and shutting the doors all drain your reserves.

The plot and the gameplay don't mesh too well, but this isn't a game you play for the plot. It's a game you play to experience that special sort of tension that comes from the fear of the unknown. You'll scramble to check your feeds as you hear kitsch music and shuffling steps echoing through the hallways, your paranoia will claw at you as you leave the video feed and the lights off to conserve power, you'll panic when the animals play peekaboo outside your door and come running down the halls looking for human blood.

This game is cheap at $4.99. If you have any love for true horror, you'll at least give this game a chance.

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. At 28
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway."

reviewText:
A great game.
Many reviews seem to be a direct response to the popularity this game has and the fandom, or the game's reliance on jumpscares.
In my opinion, doesn't any death in a horror game end as a suprise?
If you were able to see it coming, it wouldn't interest you. And therefore you wouldn't be entertained by it.

The jumpscares only work as well as they do because they immerse you into the environment so completely with the game's atmosphere and lore. It's not the same as poking a part of your brain with an electrical prod. I think that the jumpscare is a tool which is used very well here. And I believe that the small bit of terror this game gives me is exactly what it should be valued at.

It does get tedious and it is frustrating at times, but that comes with the territory. If this game would have been released in the late nineties it would have been considered a masterpiece. I feel it still is.

reviewText:
Amazingly fun horror, if you like to jump out of your chair.

This game is pretty basic and incredibly fun, there's not much to say about this game except you'll spend a fair bit of time trying to complete it and you won't give up because your bored..
The game can be incredibly difficult but is a great way to eat time up late at night.
It shows that for a game to be good you don't need good graphics, this game is locked to 720p which is okay but there are no graphics options at all.
Because of this lack of graphical settings some people will have issues playing this game with strange aspect ratios or a low resolution monitor.

Overall great game well worth the only £3.99 (at time of review) for the game. 8/10.

date: not *horrifying.* This is because there is no atmosphere or pacing which are requirements for a true horror game.  It’s also impossible to be truly horrified if you’re carrying enough weaponry to turn the installation you’re inside into ash.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: when it proudly boasts that it has tons of jump-scares?  It is because it also has the other ingredients for a true horror game:  Good atmosphere and sound engineering

The game itself takes place in a cheap ♥♥♥ pizza parlor where stuffing pizza up your ♥♥♥ is the real fun. reviewText: I recommened this game to anyone who likes horror and/or wants a challenge! This game was a brand new look/start to a different kind of horror that we're used to, you know, remember when all horror games was just Slenderman clones? This game, to some, isn't all that scary, but you got to admit, it's very tense!! It keeps you on the edge of your seat! Not to mention it's amazing backstory!! So much mystery and secrets that we still haven't even discovered yet! And to back it all up, it was made by just one guy!! Congrats Scott, you made a game that I will forever remember and even show to my kids/grandchildren! I really like this game, and if I would honestly rate it, I'd choose 9/10 :) Now time to write a review for the sequel :3

date: there comes a point where you just stop and say

Other than the survival aspect of this game (Which mainly consists of waiting to push a couple buttons) that's pretty much it. That's Five Nights at Freddy's. This game is overrated in my opinion."

reviewText: Need to make some extra cash?  Got your attention now?  Security guard needed  (no experience needed)!  All you have to do is watch over Freddy Fazbear's Pizza at night from......you know theifs and stuff.  You'll have access to 11 different cameras all around the establishment and secure metal doors if anything is to happen.....Like annoying people begging for loose change.  You will also have access to a light outside your door so you can.....see whats outside your door.  Oh whats that?  There shouldn't be anything outside your door at all.  Well anywho your shift starts at 12am and you'll be off at 6am.  The graveyard shift.  Nothing ever goes on during these hours anyway.  Its like FREE money.  Just watch some cameras, kick your feet up and close a few doors during your shift.  Oh did I mention you also have access to a telephone?  Sweet I know, and without further ado the pay.  You will recieve a solid grand total of $120 per week!  Now how does that sound?  Sign up now by clicking add to cart" and start making that CA$H!  Don't waste another minute!"

reviewText: The basic premise of Five Nights at Freddy's demands the player spend the vast majority of the game inactive. The diminishing power supply - the resource used for protection - actually incentivizes sitting still and waiting. Not that there's much that can be done, electricity or no. There are two doors, a light for each door, and series of security cameras to check. There's not even an in-game menu, esc just closes the game entirely. But surprisingly, inactivity and the helplessness that develops from that lack of options, only strengthens the inevitable jump scare. While Five Nights at Freddy's is very clear about what it has to offer, it does bear repeating: this is not a game that lends itself to speculation or any sort of terror that would outlast the experience; anticipation and jump scares are all that can be found here.

reviewText:
I used to like FNaF too. Mostly for its storyline. When the franchise was still young and beautiful I really loved this game. It felt unique and its storyline was absolutely fantastic. But now I only see a horrible monstrosity which has been milked empty. First and maybe second FNaFs were made with love and passion, but the last ones were... crap. Syrupy fanservice to milk some money. And yes, nowadays I dislike the franchise as a whole, but there IS reasons why I don't like this first game in particular.

I'm positive that almost all of the fanbase is there because of the storyline. I'm not saying the fanbase is horrible and it certainly isn't afflecting my opinion in any way. Anyway, the game itself is dull and short, almost not worth its price at all. I admit, I only liked this game for its story. I was amazed how dull it was in reality because in all the videos it looked awesome.

And that's the main reason I pressed the red thumb under this box. DON'T BUY THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE WATCHED ANY WALKTROUGHS, IT'S NOT WORTH IT! At first the idea of anomatronics was interesting and in fact scary, but after three games and so much hype they became no scarierer than basic teddy bears. Jumpscares were scary, but now when you can expect them, they are not scary at all. Believe me, watching videos about this game is much more entertaining than playing it.

Few GOOD things about gameplay features:
+ Unique and interesting systems.
+ It really can feel frightening
+ Cameras are an excellent idea.

And then there's these not so good things.
- Short. Not worth it.
- So overhyped.
- Franchise has been milked dry.
- No replay value at all.

If you are one of those very few who found this game only recently and you've not yet watched anything about this, this game is ok. I don't like its gameplay, it's something that Greenlight usually gives birth to, nothing less, nothing more. It can feel frigtening when you play it for the first time, but after watching 100hrs video material about it and played it trough 100 times, it's not so interesting anymore.

If you still like the storyline, nothing is in your way to theorize about it and attend discussion. This game can't give you any more information than let's plays do. In fact, it gives less. I strongly believe that this whole great story was born accidentally.

reviewText:
First off, this can be a really tense game, depending on how you play it and if you actually get scared from horror games (which I usually am not).  The one bad part I have encountered so far (after 3 nights in my first playthrough) is that it is not a hard game if you find the right strategy or strategies:

(Both these things are explained in game [Nights 1 and 2] and there are no big spoilers from the rest of the recordings on these nights or any other nights)
- You need to try and save 50% from 12-3 so you have the other half of battery life from 3-6, which isn't that hard if you know what to do and when to do it.  If you have a strategy that can help you do this, you'll make it to 6 AM usually, and therefore it won't really scare you as you know what to do and how to last the whole night.
- If a character is not on one of the cameras they are most likely at a door so it really eliminates any scare tactic there, unless of course, you forget that part of the recording and don't realize that until after you see it.

Overall it is a really good game, but it may benefit from having more rooms added without cameras (or ones that have blindspots where the animatronics can hide) so it eliminates the problem I have with the second point.  I'm not sure how it would be possible to fix or change the first issue I have, unless it actually does become very hard for nights 4 and 5, which I have yet to start.  If so, then the first point may not end up being a problem if you are forced to change strategies midway through the playthrough due to losing too much battery life.

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's has to be one of the most scariest games ever. Everything about it is scary. The atmosphere, the enemies,the jumpscares, it's all so scary. Especially the fact that you can't move at all and you just sit in the same room while these animatronics slowly move to your room to kill you. All these factors make a very good game, if you put them together correctly, like Scott did.

Overall, this game is very scary game and I recommend you get the game.

Are you ready for Freddy?

reviewText: Decent indie horror with an interesting concept. However, Five Nights at Freddy's has little to no replay value considering the game stops being scary after about the second night. This game is just not able to keep my interest all the way through, which is kind of sad considering how short it is. There is not enough diversity in the gameplay, and the game relies too much on jumpscares and not enough on buildup. I still recommend it, but it only just reaches over the bar of recommended-ness.\n\n6/10 - Good

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's.

This game is the biggest release of 2014.
The graphics are truley next gen, and are amazing on pc.
The intense story leaves you guessing at every turn.
So much hype, and it lives up to it.
Complex and amazing combat system, easy to learn, impossible to master.
The characters all have really amazing deep pasts.
Hours of fun.
Amazing open world, so much to explore.
The side missions are actually fun. They are all different.
FNAF is the best game of 2014.

reviewText:
Five Nights never really catched my attention. At first it seemed like another typical jump-scare game that Youtubers will just overreact about in videos. Once MatPat released his theory on the story, my interest began to grow. I started searching stuff about the game and at the peek of it all, I bought it on Steam.
The gameplay is pretty simple, you just have to monitor the animatronics at night for 6 in-game hours and keep them out from the security room you are at. You have a camera that shows most of the building to you, 2 doors that you can close and 2 lights that you can turn on to see 2 o fthe animatronics in case you can't find them on the camera. The real kicker though is that EVERYTHING DRAINS POWER. Power is basically your best friend while playing the game and it drains at a moderately slow rate when you don't use anything. The more stressed you are and francticly try to check the camera and close the doors, the more power it drains. This makes the game an interesting combination of surviving the animatronics, while at the same time trying to not run out of time. pretty unique as far as horror games go.
Speaking of horror, this game seriously has none. I am a complete ♥♥♥♥♥ when it comes to any type of scare, but this game was a walk in the park pretty much. Not even close to the scariest game ever as everyone tries to say. I will, however, say that it was mostly because of the way the game is made. It is possible to beat the game without a single jumpscare, as long as you have the skill to do it. This is good, because your own skill dictates the scares of the game. Very cool.
Let's talk about the nights, shall we?
The first 3 or so nights are pretty easy if you know what you are doing. When night 4 comes, it gets harder. Not only do you have to deal with Bonnie and Chica, which can sometimes overstay at your doors and drain too much power, but you have to deal with Foxy, who can quickly run at your office and can get you killed if you don't check him often. Freddy also becomes a threat and can be a problem if let to go close to your office. There are plenty of strategies out there on how to beat nights 3-6 and it's even possible to make Freddy and Foxy stay at their starting points the entire night, making it quite easy.
Night 7 is a custom night that you can change to your heart's desire. It's mostly just a nice end-game addition to help you practice, but if you beat the hardest possible setup, you pretty much have beat the game 100%.
The presentation is another thing where this game excells at. The dark and eerie athmosphere really has that feel of being alone at night.
In the end, the game is great. I think that it's a good entry point for people who are interested in horror and it has great mechanics, great athmosphere and a story that makes you think.
If you are interested, give it a go. It's not the easiest of games, especially when it comes to the later nights, but it is well worth it just for the experience.

reviewText:
Welcome to Fredbear's Pizza, you will ♥♥♥♥ your pants and die !
Your job is simple, monitor the Animotronics and check left and right door for  any unfriendly visitors.
Dont waste your power or Freedy will soon come and play his favorite song... then jumpscare you to death...

Five Nights at Freddy's is simple horror game with unique playstyle and amazing LORE.
The tension of Jumpscare coming will probably really scare you to death !
Sometimes called ''Jumpscare Simulator 2014''.
They are five animotronics each one with special abilities.

1:Bonnie -  Friendly Blue rabbit with really bright teeth and FUC.KING LOUD scream.He can teleport so beware ! Also he can only appear in the Left Side so dont forget to light the Corridor sometimes.

2:Chica   -  Yellow Chicken with really big eyes.She is kinda slow and will approach your office rather slowly but then she will look at you through the glass almost forever.She can only appear from Right side so chceck the corridor sometimes...

3:Foxy     - Probably the most annoying Animotronic.He is hiding in Pirate Cove and if you dont chcek him for too long or check him too much he will run across the Hallway and knock on your door if you are qucik and close them.

4:Freddy - Almost invisible motherfu.cker who is always hiding in shadows and come closer and closer to your office, until you die or light him up !

5:Golden Freddy  - Just dont look at him for too long !

80%
Jumpscare galore with amazing Story and Characters !
-Chobotik

recommended: play dead." Playing dead was his strategy to stay alive and in night 4 when he "died" That was a memory of Mike killing him. Now remember how the guys jaw looked like golden freddy's jaw? That's because the guy who got shot in the jaw is golden freddy.\n\n"

reviewText:
Oooh, this game.

Let me put it this way; I read up on all the info about it, looked through the wiki, watched several LPs of it, even looked at the cutesy fan art. And EVEN THEN, I had one hell of a chill down my spine JUST from looking at the PLAY button. Not even in the title screen, and I was already nervous.

And rightly so.

Never has keeping an eye on something been more terrifying! I swear, everytime I lost track of the robots, I was SO damn close to needing new underwear. It ESPECIALLY does NOT help my nerves when they just disable the cameras! And that's WITHOUT the fox to worry about!

Seriously, this has got to be one of, if not THE best horror game of 2014 so far! Kudos to Scott Cawthon for such an amazing, and frightening, experience!

reviewText: I had this game bought for me as a sort of dare, but looking back, I can honestly say I enjoyed it.\nIt's a really good bridge into more terrifying horror genres, or at least it was for me. See, I used to despise horror, but when this game sprung up, it did interest me. I watched three different people play through this game before I even opened it up; By the time I actually got around to playing it, I was pretty much used to the events of the game. I knew where the scares would happen and when, for the most part. The one thing that I was not prepared for was the anxiety the game created. Constantly checking your lights, or the camera to make sure no one was going to get you. Then by the time you realize that you are pretty much safe, your power runs out. When a game can actually induce so much anxiety in the player that it actually causes them to slip up and fail the game, that's when you know you have something good.

reviewText:
One of the most well made games I personally love. It has good use of the paranoia made from uncertainty, fear of losing and the things we are told are gonna be done to us if we lose and  of course, the jumpscares, but to be honest, behind the simplistic gameplay, is the real reason we love the game so.

The hidden backstory is what got me here, along with memorable characters. I won't spoil it here for those who haven't played it, but it's movie worth. The gameplay as a movie, not so much, but the story is so darn deep, that even to this day we haven't got a solid one.

Even with the prequel, it's still unclear. But the story is just too darn intriguing, and the characters are unique to me :3

If you plan on getting this, focus on the story. Trust me, you'll love it :D

reviewText:
SO much suspense in a little game!!!  Your in a Chuckie Cheeese type establishment after hours... your the security officer??  Why does Freddys need a security guard?  Well... because the Monsters come out at night of course!!
You have a limited amount of electricity to use while your on the job each night, so.... you have to use it wisely.  you can use the cameras to check where the Monsters are... if they have left their stage. or if they are still standing there like little angels.
... It can be a bit suspenseful, but that iis what I LOVE about it.  You can feel him coming to get you!!!!   And when he pops up in your face AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH   I LOVE IT!  i love the pop up scares and suspense.
Nice price, for a fun game.
Plus... if you own Garrys Mod, you can download this map and play even more deeply in the game... walking around and checking out every corner in the building.
Have fun... we did

reviewText: I enjoyed the game, even if it is a little short you can always make your custom night and play again and again. The mechanics were well thought out and the game itself was fun to play even if the story was a little weak in itself. the animatronics are cleverly thought out and makes you adapt to each one of them as individual characters rather than lumping them into one big threat, for example Foxy will only come out of pirate cove if you do not watch the cameras(including his camera) often enough or watch them constantly. This forces you to watch the cameras and maintain a balance between reserving your limited power(which constantly dwindles) and keeping an eye on the animatronics lest they try and make a break for your little closet you call a security room and shove you into a costume filled with nice little sharp and point bits of metal. I look forward to the next game this company creates and I can say 100% they have made a fan of them out of me. 10/10 Ready for Freddy.

reviewText:
So i've finished the game now, don't look up how to play correctly unless you're about to seriously give up on playing altogether (I mean watching Let's Plays, or 20/20/20/20 complete) because it makes the game much easier when you know the correct strategy, the game's jumpscares get less anticipated the more you play (shocker), but I had a terrible (in a good way) time playing this game. 10/10 I want to see a sequel that's not as good as the original but if it were a standalone it'd be considered a good game.

reviewText:
'Five Nights at Freddy's is a fantastic strategy survival horror game that is probably the most scary and most intense game I have ever played. This game will make you sweat, shiver and scream.

The idea of this game is you have been hired as a security guard at Freddy's Pizza place. Your goal is to check all the security cameras, the lights, the doors, your environment, EVERYTHING to keep an eye on Freddy and the other the animatronic droids to make sure they don't get to you. Otherwise they will see you as another droid without a Freddy costume and will try to stuff you inside of one (which will kill you). The objective of this game is to survive the night from 12:00AM to 6:00AM (each hour is around 1.5 minutes in length). You must survive all 5 nights to beat the game (The game saves at the start of each night). There is also an extra night and a custom night where you can choose the difficulty of each droid, on a scale of 1-20.

The warning for this game is This game contains a lot of Flashing Lights
date:
Loud Noises and Jumpscares" If you really cannot cope with loud noises make sure to turn your game volume down to your satisfaction. The jumpscares in this game happen when the droids get to you. They jump right into your vision and perform a very loud robotic-like scream.

This game I'd say has a horror scale of 8/10. I've always been a fan of Indie horror but this game is a masterpiece. It is scary and intense as F*CK!!! There is a free demo for this game online which only unlocks the first night. You can buy the full version for only $4:99 which is a pretty decent price for this kind of game. It's worht the money.

Overall this game is a very unique and fun idea for a horror game. I rate it 9/10
recommended: it is that good. If you are a fan of horror or Indie horror then I Highly recommend buying this game. Special thanks to IndieDB and the youtubers: Markiplier and Yamimash for introducing me to this game.\n\n"

reviewText: When I first saw this game on steam greenlight I actually had very high hopes for this, a concept of horror everyone has feared once in their lives at least yet no one has ever done anything about it. Animatronics, these bloody kind you see in children's restaurants, or used to see anyway. I had given this a thumbs up and continued to look through games since this one was indeed a nice path AWAY from those darn slender clones I kept seeing, and my god how this game has grown in popularity which makes me very, and I mean VERY, happy. This focuses on a slightly new form of horror, it's not seeing something chase you, it's not running from the generi monster trying to catch you from behind or such. This game focuses on knowing there is something after you, knowing what is after you, having the item truly traumatic to the human subconscious with something we have all feared once in our lives, and probably the biggest change here. You know it's coming, you can narrow down where they usually close in but can never predict their actions, and you have not only the feeling of pure paranoia, but have this knawing feeling in the back of your head that it is never IF they find you, never IF they  get you, every IF in a scenario that goes against your progress will always become a WHEN. This game is truly outstanding, and if a sequel is truly being made as I have heard rumors of, then it certainly has my wallet on life support out of eagerness of the awaited release date. Likely what I have said might not make sense to some people since I type things a bit oddly, but to sum up what I think, This is a stupendous game, a full 10 out of the option of 10 given. I sincerely hope a sequel is in the making, and I wish the best of luck towards the maker of this game.

reviewText: I enjoyed the game, even if it is a little short you can always make your custom night and play again and again. The mechanics were well thought out and the game itself was fun to play even if the story was a little weak in itself. the animatronics are cleverly thought out and makes you adapt to each one of them as individual characters rather than lumping them into one big threat, for example Foxy will only come out of pirate cove if you do not watch the cameras(including his camera) often enough or watch them constantly. This forces you to watch the cameras and maintain a balance between reserving your limited power(which constantly dwindles) and keeping an eye on the animatronics lest they try and make a break for your little closet you call a security room and shove you into a costume filled with nice little sharp and point bits of metal. I look forward to the next game this company creates and I can say 100% they have made a fan of them out of me. 10/10 Ready for Freddy.
